Comments_List: Basic framework of macroeconomic analyses/what have been the issues in macroeconomics
Learned  a lot of models, dynamic programming, and Matlab skills.
I learned a lot about macro models and dynamic programming.

Arrow-Debreu versus sequential markets; recursive thinking; using first-order conditions and Envelope Theorem to solve for equilibria; quantitative methods to find equilibria; macro time series; vector autoregression; asset pricing formulas and models; spillover models.
I gained a basic understanding of some macroeconomic models and skills for analysing economic models.
Solving macro models, setting up problems, matlab programming.
The course should be better organized.

I felt that the textbook used in the second part was not very student-friendly. Although there are no many student-friendly graduate level macro-textbooks, there are notes available in the internet, like Krueger's notes that are much more helpful.

The course not only provided basic framework of macroeconomic analyses (e.g. recursive equilibrium) but also reviewed a few specific issues macroeconomists have been tackling (e.g. equity premium puzzle), which may help students get some research questions.
First quarter psets were too long. Didn't get the midterm back until December. No notes or slides in the second half.
More motivation for the material in the first half.

First half lecture difficult to follow, skips many steps and not very clear.  Problem sets were pretty out of the blue--lecture did not prepare students well to do the problem sets, but exam was fair.

Second half lecture great, engaging, relevant policy applications, and problem sets also challenging yet fair and manageable.  Maybe a bit more "big picture" info on why each model is important would be nice.
This class will help student learn basic macroeconomic framework and a few specific issues, which interest even non-macroeconomic students.
Yes, and especially to graduate students in economics and related disciplines.
